Carbohydrates.question: Compare and contrast starch and cellulose. [5 marks]

Starch has helical (amylose) and branched (amylopectin) forms; cellulose is straight chains
Starch used for storage; cellulose for structural support
Amylose/amylopectin insoluble but digestible by animals; cellulose insoluble and indigestible

Carbohydrates.question: Describe an advantage of branching in polysaccharides like glycogen. [2 marks]

Carbohydrates.question: Explain why plants store starch instead of glucose. [3 marks]

Carbohydrates.question: Explain why glucose is transported in blood as monosaccharide. [2 marks]

Carbohydrates.question: Describe how condensation reactions are involved in carbohydrate metabolism. [2 marks]

Carbohydrates.question: Explain how hydrolysis reactions are important after digestion. [2 marks]

Carbohydrates.question: State one function of cellulose in plants. [1 mark]

Difference: glycogen is more highly branched than starch

Carbohydrates.question: Why are polysaccharides suited for long‑term energy storage? [4 marks]

Carbohydrates.question: Describe how the physical properties of starch relate to its role. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Compact coiled or branched structure suitable for storage

Carbohydrates.question: Explain the function of reducing sugars in metabolism. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: React in tests enabling detection in diagnostics

Carbohydrates.question: Compare and contrast the structure and function of starch and cellulose in plants. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Both are polysaccharides composed of glucose monomers
Starch is made of α-glucose; cellulose is made of β-glucose
Starch has branched (amylopectin) and unbranched (amylose) forms; cellulose forms straight, unbranched chains
Cellulose chains form hydrogen bonds → microfibrils; starch coils into compact helical structures
Starch functions as energy storage; cellulose provides structural support in cell walls
Starch is digestible by animals; cellulose is indigestible due to β-1,4 linkages

Carbohydrates.question: Describe how the structure of glycogen makes it an effective energy storage molecule in animals. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Made of α-glucose units linked by 1→4 and 1→6 glycosidic bonds
Highly branched – provides multiple ends for rapid glucose release
Compact – fits into small storage spaces
Insoluble – does not affect osmotic balance or water potential
Easily hydrolysed – enzymes can quickly break down glycogen to glucose
Stored in liver and muscle tissues – readily available energy source

Carbohydrates.question: Explain how disaccharides and polysaccharides are formed and broken down in biological systems. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Formed by condensation reactions between monosaccharides
Glycosidic bonds form during condensation; water is released
Polysaccharides form from repeated condensation of monosaccharides (e.g. starch, glycogen)
Broken down by hydrolysis – water is added to break glycosidic bonds
Enzymes such as amylase and maltase catalyse hydrolysis in digestion

Carbohydrates.question: Describe how you would test for the presence of reducing and non-reducing sugars in a solution. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Add Benedict’s reagent to solution and heat in water bath
Colour change from blue to brick-red indicates reducing sugar
If no change, sugar may be non-reducing (e.g. sucrose)
Hydrolyse sample by heating with dilute acid (e.g. HCl)
Repeat Benedict’s test – red precipitate indicates non-reducing sugar was present

Carbohydrates.question: Explain how the structure of cellulose contributes to its function in plant cell walls. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Made from β-glucose monomers joined by 1→4 glycosidic bonds
Every other glucose is flipped → allows straight, unbranched chains
Chains held together by hydrogen bonds → form microfibrils
Microfibrils are strong and form a criss-crossed network
Provides tensile strength to resist osmotic pressure and maintain cell shape
Insoluble – does not dissolve in water and provides long-lasting support
